>
>> >Another option would be to pass=
 a clean instance to the command 
>> >line parser, which then acts as a bui=
lder.. calling setters on the
>> >instance.  Then you can pass in a mock to=
 be built.. with 
>> >expectations as to *how* it will be built.
>> 
>> Hel=
lo! Ding ding ding.... that's nice.
>
>Glad you like it.
>
>> 1. Put the se=
ts on an interface.
>
>Exactly.
>
>> 2. Expose get/set on Test Implementati=
on and submit it to the 
>> builder. This tests that the builder calls the =
interface's sets 
>> correctly.
>> 
>> 3. Don't expose get on Production Im=
plementation because the outside
>>  world doesn't need them.

>Actually y=
ou don't need getters at all.  Mock the interface, and set
>expectations on=
 the set calls.  Then pass that into the
>builder/parser.  You don't need t=
o capture the args other than to
>compare them with what was expected.

For=
 some odd reason I don't like setting expectations on an object then lettin=
g it verify itself. Sounds weird. I prefer to be the one to verify it. I do=
n't know why.
